If I'm going to put in the effort to travel for mexican, I stick with El Metate, nachos to die for.
author: Alexander F.

description:
I lived right by this place for a year, so I went countless times.

However, I've only ordered the California burrito. It's unbelievable how good it is.

Being from SoCal, it pains me to admit that the best California burrito just might be in the Tenderloin of San Francisco.
author: Phatalie J.

description: 5 STARS because this is the only place that serves California Burrito for less than $8. Also it is the best Cali burrito in the city. I would definitely recommened this place. I can't get enough of that burrito.
author: Raven M.

description:
I have walked by this place while going to my mainstay-Little Henry's----I always walk by after I have eaten and almost always after 2pm-

I always read their little  breakfast specials sign in the window . 
#1, eggs, shrimp, avocado, rice, $4.55

I have no idea what they mean by the above, is it a burrito, is it a taco?, maybe a torta?----what I do know, is that I love each individual item, so how bad could it be for all 4 of them for only $4.55?

I had walked in before at around 2pm, and asked about the special before and got a puzzled look from the worker-----after shouting something in Spanish, I did get the response, it was too late for the special-------so on Sunday, same situation, un-dettered, and thinking, hey it is Sunday, brunch often happens late, I walk in again----I again ask the lady who yells back to the kitchen, after some negotiations, I get the OK wave from the man in the kitchen-----after silence and no further communications, 10 mins later, the lady motions me that the buttons she is pushing into the register is what she wants from me, then hands me the bag, no words exchanged. 

I drive off and open the lid----I learn the # 1 is literally what it says, a plate with small shrimp scrambled in eggs, a side of 3 slices of avocado, and a small side of yellowish rice-----a second bag of chip and homemade salsa, the watery, not the thick kind. 

You know what?, it was simple, and simply what I wanted----yes, the eggs were a bit over-cooked, but they were well seasoned, the rice was great, I could have eaten an entire plate of it, the avocados were fresh, the chips, while store bought, were on the salty side like I like it, and the salsa, awesome----freshly made, not vinegarry----

could not think of a better way to spend $4.55.
author: Garfield J.

description: It's so inexpensive and delicious, I'd eat here everyday if I could. If you're into fries with your mexican food, I highly recommend the california burrito or carne asada fries. SO GOOD.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Ok I was afraid when I first saw it.  I even walked by and wondered if I really wanted to try this place.  However I did take a chance (well not really a chance since I'd already seen the 4-star Yelp rating), and the food was sooooo good!

This is like eating at somebody's mom's house.  Just be careful not to over-order.  I ate so much that I almost made myself sick.  Let's just say that you shouldn't consider the carne asada fries an appetizer.
author: Hester B.

description:
First timer but I think they got a repeater in making!

Read reviews before I went, so went in and order the carne asada fries n California burrito~ took a while for the order to be ready but I can see why.. Small place but quite busy! After waiting for close to 15 mins it was ready n I picked up a Mexican cola along with the order.. Got home n boy is the order BIG! Definitely enough for 2 ppl.. N  both were items delicious!! Will definitely go back when I'm craving for Mexican food!

Mind that they only take cash (they do have an ATM machine inside)
author: may k.

description: Best burritos/latin food in the neighborhood. Also with the price for what it is! Only downside is that it is cash only, but there is an atm machine inside.
author: Cheryl P.

description:
Been buying take-out here for two+ years and I've seen changes for the better:  now they have a wheelchair ramp [good for motorized chairs, like mine].  
Health-wise, their pupusas have become a lot less greasy.
author: Corinne d.

description:
Banging, smothered, carne asada fries are truly fattening but like I said, banging.  Pupusa meal is a great deal and could keep you satisfied for your whole day and they are delicious.  
This place is only about the food and it is so affordable.  Check it out!
author: D B.

description:
Yay! I don't have to go all the way to the Mission for pupusas!

Olivo's reminds me of the kind of no-frills but honestly good restaurants you can find all over the East Bay (OAKLAND!!! :))

Solidly good pupusas.

A huge bowl of menudo in the middle of the week! 

Decent prices.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
it was a cold night, and they left the front door open, else the kitchen gets too hot.  doesn't matter that it was freezing inside the restaurant as long as the staff were comfortable.

Carnitas were dry and bland.  Cooked a few days ago and heated multiple times given how dry it was.  I wanted a small modification to the plate and they refused (I will pay you more did not help).

ambiance was weak.  worst fried plantanes i've had in the city (cooked with fresh plantanes rather than older brown ones - left strong tanic taste in mouth).

service was lackluster - never checked on us till we were done eating.  

perhaps i ordered the wrong thing, but i asked the staff first to see if it was recommended and was told it was.  i would give them 1 star but my girlfriend said she liked her food.
author: reza n.

description: Olivo's is a Salvadorian restaurant that's alright with me.  Yes, the service wasn't the best, but it was okay.  The waitress was polite enough and the drinks came fast.  We were super hungry, so it felt like a long time for the food to come.  But when it came, it was pretty tasty.  We ordered pupusas de calabaza even though it wans't on the menu.  Very tasty!  I would come back for sure.
author: Kelly K.

description: I will be honest the cross streets, the interior, and lack of people had me worried. I was dumb, it filled up quickly and the food was great. Precious reviewers questioned the service but the staff was very nice, it's a two way street. Food was great, one of the best taquerias I've had in the city after two years of consistent sampling. California burrito was great. Steal was good quality and the fries were fresh. Papusa's were great too. If you like taqueria food I think you would be doing yourself a disservice if you pass this one up.
author: John D.

description:
ONE OF THE BEST BURRITO PLACES IN THE NOBBERLOIN! Portions are HUGE. Carne asada was well seasoned and price is just right!

I only wish they open later (preferably into the wee hours of the morning) and put more meat/ less rice in their burritos. Otherwise, very satisfied!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Great place. Food and service are great. 

Plantains
Fresh cut fries
Corn pupusas
Fish tacos





Affordable-affordable!!
author: Tigre T.

description: Delicious food! Amazing plantains, salsa was too good - fresh, spicy and very flavorful.
author: Anu B.

description:
Serving up massive slabs.

The lack of wheat tortillas was made up for and then some with a ridiculous amount of tasty grilled chicken, generous helping of black beans and lettuce at no charge.

Make that serving up massive slabs of goodness.
author: Jason B.

description:
I use to go to this place often.  But you know how it happens:  you find a place that makes an incredible tongue dish for little coin and other Latin eateries fade into the distance.  Well, a recent visit to Olivio's resulted in a still overall favorable impression, but nothing even approaching eye-rolling bliss.

Neat, pleasantly decorated and maintained place (especially for the dicey neighborhood).  The salsa was good, the chips (the basket contained what looked like only smaller, broken fragments -sigh-) contained a little kick that goes well with a beer.  The grilled meats were strangely inconsistent:  chicken and beef both nicely flavorful in one mouthful, overly salty in the next, and bland in another).  The black beans were the kind of plumpness and inkiness that I really appreciate in casual surroundings.  (I love mixing other foods into the beans for different taste sensations.)  Finally, I seem to remember the salad being more than a pile of shredded iceberg and a thin twist of tomato.
author: Poet D.

description:
Yummy yum yum. An unassuming little place. I was actually hesitant to step in at first, so unremarkable it seemed. But I'm glad I tried it out.

I had the cheese pupusas with beans and rice, which was super-tasty. Very simple food, but delicious. The meal also came with nachos and salsa; they weren't anything to write home about, but whatever.

I'd certainly come back--preferably with a friend so that I can give those Carne Asada nachos a try.
author: Greg P.

description:
I was pretty excited to check out this place when I heard that they had carne asada fries. Being the deprived former San Diegan that I am, I jump at any opportunity to get my hands on this deliciousness. 

This place was severely disappointing. Though they did not microwave the fries like other NorCal places I've been to, the fries weren't all that crispy, they used the white cheese again, and the guac was just ok. The only thing that saved the dish was the meat. The carne asada was really good. Nicely grilled and super flavorful. 

Won't be going here again personally though I'm sure there are other things that are good here.
author: Kim J.

description: Been here several times, only had the carne asada fries or the california burrito. Never been let down.
author: Chris G.

description:
oh man this spot is the jam! 

so cheap too! really no frills spot right around the corner from my old job. 

carnitas, papusas, burritos, salsa/chips == all DELISH!

cash only though.
author: jaclyn g.

description:
tried this terrible place again, still terrible. 
Yelp censored my first review, and its still bad. dont censor me, yelp.
this place is truly dirty and terrible. flies and bugs ARE NEVER ACCEPTABLE.
Not only were there flies and bugs, but there is a whole laundry list of things that went wrong. Please dont go here.
go to filtered to see my first review.
author: Elliott G.

description: Insanely good California burrito with carnitas. Will sort out any hang over guarenteed.
author: Matt M.

description:
I've finally found a place in norcal that serves good california burritos!! Coming from spending four years in San Diego, my standards are pretty high, but Olivio's is definitely top notch in my book when compared to other mexican food I've tried in the bay area.

- California burritos- made with fries that are more steak fry than skinny, but still delicious! A hearty amount of avocado, cheese, and rice. I wish they were open later!!
- Pupusas- heard all about them from the reviews so we had to get some. They were warm and slightly crispy on the outside, but filled with warm and soft pork and cheese on the inside. Mmmm took some home and def ate one for breakfast. Oops.
- Plantains- a little dry and overcooked. Skip.

Will definitely be coming back to try their carne asada fries as well! Service isn't great, but I honestly wouldn't mind since their food is so good.

PS. Cash only!
author: Stefi C.

description:
Carne. Asada. Fries.  

I'll go back just for that, but the pupusas, plantains, and beans and rice are great, too.
author: M. H.

description:
Never again!!!! It was a bad experience from beginning to end with the waitress. First I walked in and the waitress didn't even acknowledge me, I had to ask her if I could sit anywhere and she had an attitude when I asked her. Then she brought the menu and disappeared. I had to go look for her to place my order. I was the only there and it took 20 mins to get my food and what I ordered was not complicated! Next she brought me eggs sunny side up which I hate and can't eat because the runny yolk makes me sick so I told her I didn't like them that way and I wanted them scrambled to which she got an even bigger attitude and replied "well you didn't tell me that so that's how they were made" and rolled her eyes and simply walked away without fixing my order! I understand that I didn't tell but usually a waiter will ask how you want your eggs or at the very least offer to fix the order! Lastly, she never returned to my table after that and I again had to go looking for her to pay the check.
Based on other reviews I'm not the only one that has had a bad experience w this lady! If they want to have repeat customers they need to get rid of that waitress or keep her behind the scenes!
author: Virginia L.

description:
So here's what's making me fat this month :

Pupusas - Cheesy fat patties from heaven. I like the cheese and pork. They give you two in an order. So I'm probably going to die about ten years sooner that I would have, had I not discovered pupusas. Totally worth it.

Shrimp Tacos - Also served in twos. Large amount of shrimp chopped into big chunks. Onions, cilantro, cheese, and a couple slices of avocado.

Beef Soup - I get the half soup & pupusas meal. If you don't know, you put lime or lemon into this kind of soup, which Olivio's includes. They are very careful to give you a nice big piece of meat and a piece or two of each vegetable- corn, zucchini, carrots, cabbage, and either potato or yucca.

Camarones Rancheros - Olivio's cannot be making money on this dish. 6 large, butterflied prawns in on of the tastiest "Ranchero" (tomatoes, onions, and bell peppers) sauces I've ever had. I spooned the excess sauce over the rice and pinto beans (also my favorite ever), then tilted the container to spoon up the last drops. Boyfriend also loves the shrimp dishes, and has their Camarones al mojo de ajo at least once a week.

Steak - Big ass steak with onions, rice and beans. Or with fries. Or with plantains and beans. Or chopped with peppers, onions, and tomatoes, rice and beans. Or breaded and fried with rice and beans. Or shredded with eggs. Or shredded with peppers, plantains, and beans. Or with yucca and cabbage salad. Or with a cheese enchilada! ALL FOR $9.50-$10!!!!!!!

Chicken - I thought they gave me a ton of chicken. Then I realized there was yet a second layer beneath it. I think their fries are okay, but I prefer to have the pinto beans and their rice, which is super tasty. Or I have it with their yucca, which is kinda like gigantic french fries. The chicken is also available in many of the same preparations as the steak.

As if that weren't enough, Olivio's also offers several pork dishes, sole, tilapia, calamari, and crab enchiladas. AND they do breakfast. I haven't tried any of these items so I don't know how they are. But just reading the descriptions made me want to put the menu in my mouth.

Pretty much the only thing Olivio's doesn't do outstandingly is decor. Take out is definitely the way to go. Besides, you'll want to eat at home so you can unbutton (or remove) your pants.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Since my work place is very close to here and as a vegetarian I don't have much options left for NO MEAT, I decided to give Olivos a try.

I tried their pupusas.  It is so great and stuffed me up so full that I couldn't eat anything else!

But my favorite from this restaurant is their Quesadilla Suiza.  It can come with meat but I asked for no meat option.

Thin yet chewy on the outside wrapping the melted mozzarella cheese + chopped green onions + chopped onions + huge slices of avocados....this is the best quesadilla I've ever had.  Nothing top this with a side order of french fries.

Their french fries are steak cut fries where you can tell they actually cut up a potato and deep fry it.  Sprinkle it with some salt, you have the best greasy tasty french fries in the world!

I get food from them almost 3 times a week at lunch!  My coworkers also say they have the best burritos and lunch specials!  Must try!
author: Helen M.

description:
Really good Salvadorian joint... I had their famous Carne Asada Fries and the PORK PUPUSAS (AWESOME!). That was good for lunch AND dinner. 
I ordered to go but the place itself didn't look "dirty" as describe in previous reviews.
I wish the food came faster since I was in a rush... but it's cool... the taste makes it up!
author: Christian P.

description:
Reading the other reviews, I'll say that I didn't use the restroom so can't comment on that. The service was not the best.. at first. But I think the server started to like us.. we love hole in the walls, ethnic food and we were genuinely excited to be there so it showed. 

We moved from San Antonio so was missing some good mexican food. Didn't know this place also served Salvadorean food so bonus! Ordered horchata for drink which was really good. I thought I'd start out with the yucca frita served with chicharron as that sounded small and appetizer-like (it's huge). Also ordered the cheese and pork pupusa with black beans and rice. Partner ordered the asada with refried beans and plantains. Ok let me break this down.. hands down, the chicharron would have to be my favorite! I love fried porky things and this was absolute delicious. The yucca frita.. delectable. I loved the black beans and rice, even if they were just a little bland. The pupusa was good, although I've never had one before. Maybe on the average side. Asada was ok, had better. But plantains were so yummy.. loved them. Refried beans were up to par with best we've eaten in San Anto. Portions were really big. You'll def be full even if you just order one dish. And it's on the cheaper side.. $27 for all 3 dishes and drink (cash only!)

Yes, the people who worked there looked sad and unhappy, or I don't know, and it carried over to the quality of service.. for us though it got better. But we don't care too much about that as in this case, the food speaks for itself. We live in the neighborhood so yup we'll be back!
author: Vol T.

description:
Easily one of my favorite places to go when I have a craving for a tasty burrito. I'm originally from San Diego where Mexican food is everywhere and there's a wide variety of burrito styles, so I'm always bummed out when I walk into a Mexican food joint and the only options are "Burrito" and "Super Burrito".

Olivo's definitely has a lot more to offer. My personal favorite is the California Burrito (key ingredients include - guacamole, meat, and potatoes/french fries), which serves as both a great hangover cure and five times the amount of calories anyone would need in one day (aka it's freaking delicious). I used to eat these all the time back home and now Olivo's is only one of two places I've found in the city that can serve up an awesome California Burrito that reminds me of the good old days.

On top of everything, the prices are very reasonable and the service is great. The decor is what you would hope for in a cozy, Mexican food joint, nothing corny and still has a genuine style to it. There's also the option to sit down or take out, so if you're on the go or ready to settle and get comfortable, Olivo's can pretty much serve the gamut.
author: Anthony C.

description: Carne Asada fries. Huge portion, lots of cheese, guacamole and all the fixings. It's like super nachos, but instead of chips it's fries. Its of course very greasy and can be shared amongst friends. Definitely for people having the munchies.
author: Ellie J.

description: I definitely ordered the wrong thing off the menu.  I should have gotten the pupusas.  You always get the pupusas!  Anyway, in my stupidity, I ordered the fried yuca and fried pork with cabbage salad.  The fried pork was delicious, but as I should expected, only 66% meat.  The fried yuca also was generally tasty, but dry and there was no dipping sauce to be found.  The salsa did an ok replacement job.  As for the cabbage salad, they decided to shower it with an entire grove of citrus.  I couldn't stomach more than a quarter of it.  So like I said, probably entirely my fault.  Also, you have to pay at the counter.  Sitting with an empty plate and your wallet out at your table will not get the job done.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I work in the Tenderloin, and sometimes I just don't want to hop on BART to 16th & Mission during lunch.  I was so happy to find a pupusa place within walking distance of the State building.  Been cravin' some pupusas, so I figured I'd give Olivo's a try.  I'm glad I did.  For $9, I got 2 pupusas (cheese and pork), rice and beans, and a glass of horchata.  I was full, happy and satisfied.  The pupusas were very good.  Now if they'd add a jalapeno and cheese pupusa, I'd be happy as a pig in $hi+.  

Ok, so not making fun of Spanish-speaking people (my husband is from Cuba), but a horchata pupusa sounds so naughty to both my husband and me.
author: Gigi M.

description: The food was delicious but the WORST customer service. The waitress was beyond rude.  We get seated we ask for hot salsa. She says their restaurant only has one salsa. Ok, rude.  Our menus come a couple minutes later.  When we order our food she seems annoyed. We ask for chips and salsa and she says she needs to give the other table their food before us.  UMM, no one said give it right away, we just asked for it!  She gives us the food and doesn't give me a plate. I ask for one a couple minutes later and she yells in Spanish at someone in the kitchen as she rolls her eyes at us.  Sorry, it is so much trouble to get a plate! But, who doesn't give 2 plates when someone orders nachos to share?   She did not want to be there and was extremely rude. I would not recommend this place unless you order take out when you'll have limited interaction with the waitress.
author: Moni K.

description: Great little hole in the wall!  I've been here twice now for dinner.  They also serve breakfast, so I'm definitely hitting it up the next time I have to nurse a hangover.  I had been looking for good Mexican food in the neighborhood but had been disappointed by what I found -- until I tried Olivo's, that is.  The cheese enchiladas were great.  And the salsa's good and spicy.  I have yet to try the Salvadorean food, but I intend to get pupusas one of these days.  The service has been great, too.  Liz was my waitress both times, and she remembered me the second time I went in.  She was super friendly and attentive.  I have no complaints and am looking forward to many more meals here!
author: Nicholas N.

description:
Returned last weekend for a 2nd go-around and it was super solid food!

Everything is very much homestyle and family-run. They don't try to be pretentious and over do it just to cater to the standard SF sensibilities. Olivio's just does what it does and does it well. No complaints, just serious kudos for consistency and very reasonable prices.

Breakdown...
- 2 papusas made fresh for about $5.
- 2 item combo w/ beans, rice and choices of buritto, enchilada, tostada, tacos & other choices for $7.50...I had carnitas buritto and a chicken taco
- fiancee had a milenesa w/ fries for $8.50

Rice was perfectly cooked for spanish type of rice...pretty hard to do. Chicken was cooked on flat top similar to carnitas too make it a little crunchy; unique and good w/ a pile of guac on top.  Now we know milenesas well cause the GFs family is from S. America, these were different than what we are used to because the meat is a different type of cut but it was still good. 

I highly recommend this place! Don't expect to be catered to here, but do expect to leave full and pleasantly satisfied.
author: Nick V.

description:
Carne asada fries in SF?! Bf and I were so hyped up to finally get our hands on carne asada fries in the city that it ended up in a big disappointment. I've never had a chance to experience it down south (SD), but from how my friend's have raved about how good it is there, I hope it's nothing like this. 

- Carne asada fries: piping hot soggy fries with an OD of cheese, fresh onions (yuck), jalapenos, sour cream, guac, and pieces of steak. I was only able to handle a few bites before I felt a little queasy from the overly cheesy mess (Artery clogging, fo sho!). Luckily, a can of Pepsi came to my rescue and washed it all down nicely. 

- Chicken Super Burrito: nothing to rave about. It came out really simple, but it was flavored mediocre at most. Rice, chicken, fresh onions (ugh!), guac, sour cream. I needed to use the spicy salsa that came with our chips to accompany it to make it more flavorful. 

This restaurant looks like it only consists of a small hallway upon walking in, but they have additional seating in a room to the left. Service was pretty quick and efficient. After my carne asada fries experience here, next vacation food stop...SD!
author: Tracy T.

description:
Another TL gem.  I lived around the corner of this place for over a year.  Everything has the amazing homemade flavor and incredibly cheap.  I owe them some of the weight I inevitably gained with working 9 to 5.  Though I ate there regularly, I must admit that I stuck to the pupusas, burritos, carne asada french fries, and some of the meat dishes.  

The pupusas were described as "the best pupusas I've had since I was in El Savador" by a Salvadoran colleague of mine and "the best pupusas I've had in SF" by another Salvadoran colleague both of whom I surprised with this treat.  The burritos are enormous and flavorful.  I must admit that they are heavy on the rice and beans, but all the better!  It's large enough where you still get an adequate amount of meat and other goodies.  My boyfriend and I usually just cut them in half--well, those few occasions where we managed to restrain ourselves--and save the rest for the next day.  Like many latin places, they serve chips and salsa with all their meals, including their to-go orders.  The only difference is that their salsa is yummy, flavorful, and made with love.  The latter Salvadoran colleague actually taught me how to make the salsa the Salvadoran way after eating there with her.

My only regret was not trying more of the food they had to offer while I lived so close.
author: Daniel F.

description:
Oh heck yes this place is good! Cheap and delicious! Never had I ever had a pupusa before coming here and I've decided that they complete me. Black beans and cheese wrapped in warm fluffy goodness? I've decided that one of my favorite textures for food is melty (like good melty cheese) and pupusa's are exactly that. 

I got the soup to go along with my pupusas which I decided was a good choice, because it's always good to have some vegetables, and they give you big pieces of veggies in their soup. 

Salsa here is good and spicy too! And you can get the real Mexican coke.
author: Claudia T.

description:
After wanting Mexican food for the past few days, I figured I'd check Yelp for a decent Mexi place close to the hood (not the Mission) to get some carne asada. What did I find? Carne asada fries.

I figured I'd go check out what all the hype was with these carne asada fries.

First, cash only at this place. No cards. No checks. Just cash. A couple of girls who were in here when I arrived had to scrounge up some change in their car to pay for their bill. Come prepared with cash!

Also, don't wear anything nice (or anything that needs to be dry cleaned). I was hit with the greasy smell as soon as I stepped through the door. Nonetheless, I (along with my Gap t-shirt and my North Face fleece) left smelling greasy too.

Now for the food. Not the cheapest of all Mexican food places, but definitely not going to cause major damage to your wallet. I got the carne asada fries con queso, sin guacamole, onions, jalapenos, etc., etc., etc. It just seemed like too much! So just meat, fries, and cheese. Along with the salsa that I got with my free chips. The serving was huge!!! It was a whole plate of carne asada fries! No wonder I got weird looks from the employees! (Don't forget, I'm a 4'11", very petite Asian girl...and I came by myself.) It was pretty yummy, although my body can probably only handle it once or twice a year. Can you say "heart attack on a plate"? I finished almost half of it. The lady at the front asked me if I didn't like it. I told her I loved it, but it was just too big. (Also, the cook in me wishes they used cheddar instead of whatever cheese they used--mozzarella?)

I say, come here whenever you feel like it. I've lived in the neighborhood for about two years...have passed by this place almost on a weekly basis and it's not too crazy busy. Try the carne asada fries! Bring someone with you too!
author: Maureen B.

description:
I was basically brought up by an El Salvadorian nanny named Lydia (Hottie, too bad i was like 3). By the time I was 4 or 5 she was making me papusa's. When I went to college, I was taking classes at USC and basically living on Vermont and 30th at a friends place around the corner from Campus. His family was El Salvadorian and I ate there almost every night. Over the past couple years I've heard about Olivo's from friends, found it on Yelp, and finally thought I'd give it a try. 

QuickNote: Olivo's was on Market x 1st for 15 years and in their new location for 2 years. Its just on the N. Edge of the Tenderloin, and the S. Edge of Nob Hill. Great Location. 

What I love about Olivo's is its family owned and operated. So love goes into every dish. Jose the chef and his wife Antonia (who takes care of the front of house) were wonderful, they laughed with me even though I'm just a white kid from the west side who purports to know what El Salvadorian food is actually about. The least I can say is I have a good idea. Their son Frank asked me if I've ever had Carne Asada Fries (which were on my plate), and of course I said I've never even heard of them, but they were off the hook. I was taking about 1/3 home and he said they are fresh cut and cooked and may not reheat very well. I gave it a shot with a touch of canola oil and they fried up med-brown and incredible). We had a split of 2 papusas, side of black beans and those Carne Asada Fries, and these pounds will not shed without a good, long session of something. 

Beverages are well priced (Sodas $1, 12oz Beers $2-3, 32oz beer $5). Meals are all around $10. Breakfast $6, Burrito's $6.

A guy came in and ordered a burrito (obvioulsy a student) and he asked $5 (even though they are $5.95+)? And jose says... um yes $5. Nice. 

So... I will be back.... and I will be back for the Carnitas!

By the way... I hate to say it but... Jose and Antonia's Papusas were better than anything i had in my youth. Thats why they are getting a solid 5 stars. 

CASH ONLY
author: Adam X.

description:
The first thing into my mouth, A stale store bought chip . My guess is Casa Sanchez brand, And I'll put a weeks pay on a bet! The salsa was also reminiscent of ....ah Casa Sanchez ! 
The Pork taco , not bad . A little salty though.
Chili relleno was actually a fire roasted poblano. not bad!
The papusa was soggy , but not flavorless, just not good. The slaw tasted of to much oregano , and lacked any vinegary punch. 
Over-all I have had much better off of a roach coach .
I would not return.
author: Fat ass g.

description:
I was sooo excited that there was a place in SF with carne asada fries.  However, it was nothing like from what I remembered when I had it in San Diego.  

The fat fries came out hot and soaked in oil and it seemed like there were at least 5 layers of cheese on top of the fries.  After a couple bites I felt like a I was shaving a couple of years of my life expectancy.
author: Danny P.

description:
loves olivio's so much ... have been stalking the food for over 17 years mow -- first when he was on 24th street in the mission and then on 3rd street downtown.  i was last there two days ago, having my usual combination platter (you can mix and match) with a beef taco, a grilled pork and melted cheese inside a grilled tortilla, and a chili  rellenos.  they give complimentary chips and salsa.

the food portions have stayed the same, as the quality too.  (recently went to a chain mexican restaurant and their quality and portion size diminished somewhat and noticeable with a price hike.)  olivio's strives to stay competitive with quality and portion assurance. 

i spoke with the lady waitress after i witnessed her greeting new arrivals to the restaurant in a quick and professional manner.  i told her i read old reviews of her and so please, discount any bad reviews of service.  this is a family style service restaurant. so if you need something, just ask politely or if you are a regular like i am, i scream it.

they have beers, juices. soft drinks there if you need it.  they menu is varied somewhat and yet have to try everything
author: Tamara C.

description:
A burrito with discrete ingredients is a rarity this far north of the border, and it's always nice to find one of the places where such a treat can be acquired. Wrapped inside a tortilla is actually one of the few places I prefer meat to vegetables, and the carnitas at Olivo's makes my taste buds happy every time. It manages to have crispy edges while maintaining a deliciously tender, chewable texture, and partnering excellently with the smooth flour, flavorful rice, better-than-usual-quality cheese, fresh salsa, and delectable beans that make up the remainder of said burrito. Aside from the famous carne asada fries and signature pupusas, the nachos are solid alternative, with the same tempting components piled high on chips that actually have some body - so that you can taste more than a hint of corn -  instead of simply being a wafer-thin vehicle for condiments.

The staff are all incredibly friendly people, more than willing to accommodate a special request or recommend something to fill your stomach. The very first time I came here it was near closing time, and having failed to notice the prominent "Cash Only" signs, was only packing plastic. The lovely woman working the counter was nice enough to let me take my dinner away sans payment, and with only the promise of returning tomorrow with the eight bucks I owed. As a last note, while the transvestites that flock to the corner of Post and Larkin can be rather intimidating, I find that carrying an extra cigarette or two to hand out will turn them friendly in a hurry, although that has a tendency to make them think I want to proposition them - do I really look all that much like someone who would engage their services?
author: Alex B.

description: Pupusas are delicious. La Carne asada with onions was fantastic. And great and helpful service.
author: Gary M.

description:
Yelpers are fucking rabid. You treat carne asada fries like it was the biggest crack rock in Modesto because when I went to Olivo's today, the chef came out of his kitchen and asked why so many people came in and asked for carne asada fries. Yes, it's not embarrassing *at all* having to tell the sweet oompa loompa like short order cook senior that you are part of a fatty fat fat social network group on the *coughcoughinternetcoughcough*

The carne asada fries were pretty good. The cheese was a little too melty and a bit too many onions on the guac for my taste... but even mediocre carne asada fries trump chump ass nachos any day. mmmm. I also got un typo of each pupusa: queso, queso con frijole y queso con pork..... i don't remember the word for pork.

Damn you Mr. Vernalde and 3 years of High School Spanish!?! Donde es la biblioteca? Es proximo aqui? Gracias! Hasta semana! The only other Spanish I know fluently is Spanish mass. Padre nuestro que estas en los cielos, santificado sea tu nombre, venga tu reyno. *screw you, mom... get out of my head Jesus!*

While I was waiting, the lady at the counter even gave me an impromptu Spanish lesson. (Which I give her mad props for. It takes a lot to reach out to a sad sad Asian girl and teach her how to say "More sour creme please"... "Mas nata agria, por favor!". You really don't know how handy that is to me (Answer: Immensely!) But I'll stick to English. Still, gracias para la comida.
author: Mary F.

description:
What a great find ! This is great place for Mexican/Salvadorian cuisine. Sure its in the middle of beautiful Tenderloin Heights but the food is just delicious. Everything is fresh and hot. The salsa they use can be really spicy at times - Their super nachos is the best I have ever had ( it blows away Chevy's) 
They also make FANTASTIC Pupusas, soup and the beef they use in their steak dishes is really fabulous and tender..
The place is clean, the kitchen looks fine to me . They have enough staff back their to maintain cleanliness
The waitress(s) - all I can say is - if youre polite to them they will be nice to you, because of the neighborhood they have to have a little edge to them. And at times it can be slow but at the same time who wants to rush for dinner. You can relax, have a good meal with friends - have a beer, look at the window and watch drug dealers and hookers pass by :)
Thrilling isnt it. Despite it being in the human zoo capital of SF this place is really worth going to - highly recommended
UPDATE - I recently had Carne Asada French Fries. Imagine super nachos but with fries instead, with TONS of gooey cheese and also had their fish tacos
Outta bounds ! This place should be on Guy Fieri's Diners Drive Ins and Dives !
author: David S.

description: Staff isn't the most attentive, but they are always happy to help. The food is always amazing and fresh. The salsa is fabulous and the I crave the guacamole often. I'v vegetarian and have never had any issues with my order coming out right. Always happy with how reasonably priced and fast the food and service is. I will always head to Olivo's for my mexican food cravings. If only they were open REALLY late.
author: Azlynn T.

description:
Never have I felt the need to protect my husband...but my instinct kicked in when this tranny (and a very terrible looking one with really smeared lipstick) tried to grab a passerby's crotch!  At that point, I was on guard and ready to beat this person to the pulp IF he dares get close to my hubby.  

We got into Olivo's safely.  Walking in, you feel like you walked into a family's kitchen.  It's nothing fancy and truth be told, we would have never noticed this place if we weren't looking for it.  

We took a seat at the lower level.  We came here because of the carne asada fries we read about on Yelp and the picture really made us drool... We also wanted to try the pork and cheese pupusa and asked the lady what else she would recommend and she asked if we would like to try her taco.  Sure, let's do carnitas soft taco with everything.

We munched on the chips and salsa while waiting.  The salsa was very good and we had to get refill.

The pupusa ($4) came first - they split them onto 2 plates for us and came with a bowl of marinated slaw.  The pupusa was pretty big and it looked grilled and not fried, which is good.  We were hooked after the first bite - it was soft and chewy with tender pork and cheese pulling - it's like a soft quesadilla but better.  

Next came the carnitas taco ($4) - it looked so good...I had to dig in before it got cold and was very happy with it.  It was so flavorful and there were so much meat.  This turns out to be my favorite dish of the night.

Finally the infamous carne asada fries ($6.50) came - it was just like the photo.  We were not disappointed at all.  The fries were not crispy but it was real potato so it was almost like eating a mashed baked potato with all the goodies on top.  The carne asada was SO good...every morsel was tasty, add that to pulling cheese, fresh guacamole and I see why so many raved about it.

The Regia at 32 oz. was a good deal for $5.95.  It was icy cold and they give you too icy cold mugs with it - icy cold beer is happiness!

The ladies there were very nice and checked in often.  

We were fulfilled and happy...all at a price of $21!  We will return even if I have to watch out for my husband.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Just got back from this place less than 15 minutes ago.  My boyfriend and I wanted Mexican so we decided that Olivo's would be good because of the reviews.  Sometimes even Yelp can lead you awry.

We walked in and were ignored, and asked the lady behind the counter if we should just seat ourselves.  She nodded.  The place was decent looking so we had a seat.

The waitress was very rude to us the whole time.  Everyone else was served complimentary chips except for us.   We asked for them multiple times to no avail.  My boyfriend finally went up to the counter to ask again, and the ladies just laughed at him.  What is that about?

I asked if I could have my fish tacos on hard shells instead of soft.  The waitress immediately said "Probably not.  No."  Then when she asked the chef she told me it would be fine.

The food was okay, definitely nothing to yelp about.  3 or 3.5 stars.  The service in the negative stars.

When the check came the numbers were a mess so I couldn't read the prices.  Before leaving, I looked back into the kitchen and the lady making the guacamole was also licking it up off her fingers and double dipping.  Needless to say, that turned me off to my leftovers so I quickly unloaded by doggie box on the nearest homeless person.

Highly unrecommended and we will never return.
author: Lisa X.

description:
Easily the best Mexican/El Salvadorian restaurant in San Francisco and without question, the best pupusas I have ever eaten!

I stopped in on a Tuesday evening after a pretty rough day and immediately felt relaxed. It was like I was back in New York and my parents were whipping up some of their home cooking - except that my parents aren't Mexican, but you know what I mean. The stuff that makes everything better. Simple, unpretentious, authentic, delicious. 

I ordered a chili relleno and a couple pork & cheese pupusas. In my foodiest dreams (that's right, foodiest), I could not have imagined a more prefect preparation of these dishes. The El Salvadorian-style rice and pinto beans were served exactly as expected and the chili relleno was a nice, meaty poblano stuffed with the salty mexican cheese you'd expect and fried just right - crispy and not at all greasy. 

The pupusas were thick, hearty and stuffed with just right amount of cheese and pork. Their crispy outside and chewy inside was right in every way! Just thinking about them is making my mouth water.

Also of note: the salsa! As soon as I sat down, I knew Olivo's would be awesome. You know why? Because all truly authentic Mexican and El Salvadorian restaurants have awesome, super spicy salsa...and they serve it with a plastic spoon! That's how they roll at Olivo's. Yeah baby.

A few other points:
- The chips are crap - as is the case at most good, authentic places of this sort. I find that places with good chips have crappy food. (Chevy's anyone?)
- The place is ugly inside. The fake wood paneling and odd art (a poster of El Salvadorian money?) is not much to look at, so bring a pretty dinner companion and focus on her/him and the food.
- They don't accept cards. Cash only.
- Beer is $2.95!

I feel quite certain that I'll be a regular here. I can't wait to try the menudo.
author: Brad L.

description:
My arteries are clogging as I write this, so if I keel over and die before I finish, you'll know why!  My Last Will and Testament is in my Safe Deposit box.  Blame it on the Carne Asada Fries.

ONLY in San Francisco can you find a Mexican / Salvadorean restaurant in a sea of Vietnamese restaurants.  

After having some Carne Asada Fries at the San Jose Flea Market, my roommate was dying to try the version from this place, another great find from Yelp.  In case you've been under a rock, these an "Irish" version of nachos.  Instead of chips, fresh French Fries are covered with steak, cheese, guacamole, sour cream, jalapeno, and onion and cilantro upon request.  I like them so much better than regular nachos, as I'm not crazy about beans.   I think I may have found a new staple!  But, I am trying to lose weight, so this would be a treat.

I also bought some pupusas.  They were great, but only because of the hot sauce that comes with the meals.  I don't think that pupusas is traditionally served with hot sauce, but it works here!  Not the best in San Francisco, as I wanted more filing, but still a good deal at $3.75 for two.

The Carne Asada Fries are not on the menu, but they knew I was Yelper because that seems to be the only way people find out about them.  It's nice to think that this can possibly only exist to us Yelpers.

Note that Olivo's is CASH ONLY!
author: Michael M.

description: this is my neighborhood go to for a burrito, tacos, and I'm obsessed with the plantains. Don't expect the friendliest service or fine dining but it's pretty quick, high quality, and delicious.
author: TJ H.

description:
Pupusas, chili verde, and trannys are way better when put in a sack and shaken. 

Olivo's is that sack!
author: Shannon V.

description: No idea why this place has 4 stars. Kinda ghetto which made me think the food must be good then... Not really. Pretty pricy for 2 tacos. Nothin on them. Just the meat. Which was also very dry. Oh well...
author: Iain L.

description:
Carne Asada Fries - They have them and its reason enough to come here and they're better than at other places.  Just step over the crackheads on the sidewalk, run past the tranny hookers and come to Olivo's. I'd recommend the Chicken Quesadilla or anything with Steak. 

The menu is extensive and the prices are reasonable (easily under $12 per person with appetizers) The proprietors seem pretty nice and the service isn't bad. But you will have to go up and pay yourself, just fyi.  Also remember to bring cash, since that's all the take.  The place has a nice vibe too, some other review mentioned NY feel and I agree.  
Their Salvadorean food is delicious and you should try it if you want to stray from the regular taco or burrito you always get.  

Bottom Line: Just give Olivo's one try. You could pretend you're going to Central America and a beautiful seniorita (Olivia?) comes up to you and winks and asks you to follow.  Intrigued, you go along and discover that not only is she gorgeous but also extremely competent... at cooking.
author: Dmitry S.

description:
The food was actually quite good but I'm giving 2 stars for some of the crappiest service I've had in the city.  We went early on a Thursday night and when we sat down there was two other tables seated already - one already had their food and the other had already ordered.  From the time the woman came to take our order to the time we actually got our food was 25 minutes.  Now if this was some crazy fine dining and I was sipping some wine with all that, I wouldn't care at all.  But I ordered a f'n veggie burrito.  I could have run down to the corner store and gotten some tortillas and made my own burrito with a faster turnaround.  

On the way out, I looked into the kitchen and there were 3 or 4 people back there and like I said, it was pretty slow in the dining area so I can't imagine what the hold up was.  We actually got the food and immediately had to ask for the check and boxes to go since we hadn't planned on it taking so long. 

But again, the food was actually pretty tasty.  Just not 25 minutes tasty.
author: Matt S.

description:
Oh my god, this place is good! I walk by it all the time, but it took the Living Social $1 lunch to get me in there and now I'm hooked. The deal came with a two item combo platter, so I chose a chicken quesadilla and a carne asada burrito. These are obviously smaller sizes than if you ordered an entree, but its way more than enough. I'm saving my burrito for dinner cause I'm stuffed. The rice was weirdly delicious - I mean, it's rice, right? But they do something to it, not sure what, but it was so yummy.

And I ordered black beans thinking instead of my usual refried and mixed in with the rice they were even more delicious. I actually ate my sides first! Who knew a chicken quesadilla could be that good? I'm still not sure if it was the cheese or the slightly crispy chicken edges or what, but it was really delicious. Then there are the chips & salsa. The salsa is great, but not unexpected, but the chips have a texture I've never had before. I can't even explain how they crunch, but they're sooo good.

I can hardly wait for dinner knowing the burrito is waiting for me.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Good, inexpensive Salvadorean/Southern Mexican food.  Breakfast served until 11:00.  Generous portions with combinations; I'll have to go back to try the Pupusas.  A bit heavy on the cheese.  Tamal tasted good, moist, and healthy (not coronary inspiring amounts of lard).  They have aforementioned beers, wine, aguas frescas, and sodas.

Staff is friendly, with Mexican style hospitality (they don't bring the check to you before you're finished; you may have to get up and walk to the register).
author: YearOf M.

description:
I hit this place up last weekend for a friend's birthday.  Being a part of the fantastically helpful online community that is Yelp, I knew what to expect......and to also order the carne asada fries.  One of my friends took a look and just simply said, "I can't eat those.  I'm afraid I'll shit my pants later."  A valid excuse to be sure, but the mere threat of self defecation isn't enough to stop me from indulging in this bit of artery clogging heaven.  

The rest of the grub was great as well.  Having never been to an El Salvodoran restaurant before, I hit up the pupusas and were not disappointed.  Someone else had the flank steak and it was cooked and spiced to perfection.  The massive Regia beers washed all of this culinary goodness down perfectly.  And the best part?  The total bill was $81 for 7 of us.  Yes, you read that correctly.

The only knock on this place is that the service was a little slow, but that's to be forgiven as I only spied 3 people working in the entire restaurant - and that includes the cook.  But you can bet your ass that I'll be back.
author: Norm U.

description:
A couple of months ago, I went kind of SoCal nostalgic and wanted carne asada fries, so a friend and I searched Yelp and lo and behold - a restaurant IN the city that carries one of my favorite (and missed) meals.

The first couple of times I've gone, the restaurant was closed or was just closing. That annoyed the heck out of me, so one day, as soon as I got off work - my buttocks drove out to Olivo's just so that i can sample the NorCal version of carne asada fries.

It's not on the menu - it's like one of those secret orders kinda things - so you have to ask for it. It took awhile to make it, and i have to say that i'm impressed. It will definitely satisfy my cravings for carne asada fries if ever i have a moment of weakness, and want it.

The only thing that was different was the amount of condiments on it. Guacomole could be more, and the fries could be a little bit bigger. But hey, you can't be picky about something that isn't as readily available as it is in SoCal, so I say, "yay! i'm a fan of Olivo's carne asada fries!" =)

anyone wanna go?
author: J D.

description:
this place was cheap, but it was okay

i had carne asada fries i was kinda disappointed in them, it had no comparison to the real deal in san diego. their good for what you can find in san francisco, but not as good as san diego. my friend had the puposas, she said they were okay and her carne asada was kind of hard to cut. service was friendly though.
author: Stella J.

description:
Pupusas.

They're almost as much fun to say as they are to eat.  Gosh, the corn meal is just so freaking good. It reminds me of my jefita's freshly made tortillas de maiz.

Why is it that we don't have many places that serve those amazing little things in Phoenix?  You've got more Mexican food joints on every street corner than Starbucks there, and that's saying a lot.  Very few Central American restaurants, for shame.

I introduced my little bro to pupusas through this joint, and I've got him hooked.  

Affordable, quick, delicious. Or, as Dora has taught little blonde-haired, blue-eyed kids all across the US to say, "Delicioso!"

So what if they screwed up the kind of beans I ordered (I said black, not pinto). They were still so good, I almost wanted to give them a call to thank them.

What's all this talk about carne asada fries?  Hrmm.
author: Manny P.

description:
I'm giving Olivo's 4 stars, I wish i could give it 4.5 but yelp is only into integers so 4 stars will do, and that is good in my book, I'm a tough critic when it comes to this type of Latin American food. 

The queso y frijol Pupusas are great, chips are good, salsa is great, atmosphere is really chill (reminds me of a NY spot) , oh and the plantains are very good as well, i love plantains and they are hard to go wrong on, but surprisingly people do falter on plantain preparation, not here at Olivo's.

I got a fish burrito from Olivo's yesterday for lunch and it was huge and tasty, one thing that i would have appreciated  is if they had grilled the outside of the tortilla a bit more (as places like Can cun do so well), but i didnt know and next time i will ask.

Downsides is closed on Sundays (temores) and no take out menu, you have to know the menu well or do as i did a while ago and took pictures of the entire menu to have on file.

Overall though, thumbs up- foods is tasty and family who runs it is nice - i almost wish they were one block closer to van ness on polk cause they would get more business most likely (people i think just dont know it is there) but as is its fine and tasty, Support them !
author: James A.

description:
Didn't expect much from the carne asada fries and I was correct. It definitely nothing like San Diego's but it's better than nothing. The fries are softer and there aren't as many toppings. What helps make carne asada great is the marinade which wasn't that impressive here. Meat was a bit more lean to my liking. This was my first time having pupusas so I didn't know what to expect. They weren't bad but they were not great either. I have to say my favorite dish was the California burrito. These were actually pretty flavorful and tasted great (though still not close to SD). One big plus is that Olivo's offers Mexican cola, which comes with real sugarcanes rather than syrup!

Overall, this place is okay. No real complaints but it's kind of your typical store.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
HELL YEAH! Este lugar es el mas chingon de la vecinidad!  No bullshit, brothas and sistas... Whenever I am hungry the first place I think of going to is Olivo's.  The food is very traditional, and the environment is like my grandma's kitchen.  Recommend the milanesa, which is very tender, and the papusas rebueltas con frijoles refritos y arrozzzzzz.  Also, don't forget to wash it all down with a delicious Regia brew and if you got a sweet tooth try some Horchata,which is the best this side of market street. 

Good neighborhood eatin' and the family that runs the place is very sweet and polite.  Highly recommend it.
author: smokey r.

description:
Based on Liz' review - I had to check out this place. I love pupusas and feel the tenderloin is a trove full of tiny gems of restaurants - tiny gems which think they are rhinestones, specifically.
We split a dish of pupusas (pork & cheese and bean & cheese) and plaintains with beans.  -- You can probably tell, I'm a bean fan. 

This was a family run restaurant and it felt like it.  The greetings were warm and friendly.  Questions were answered politely and there was a nice vibe.  While waiting for everything to arrive, we scoped out everyone else's food - there was a wonderful looking fried fish that I nearly snatched off an elderly woman's plate.  I will have to try it if I can ever bring myself to step away from the pupusas. 

The food was hearty, very reasonably priced and tasty. It's not chez panise, but if you want some home style stick to your ribs food for under a fiver, you've got your spot.   If I could, I'd call it a 3.5, but based on the friendly atmosphere and prices, I'll push it to 4 stars.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
Very good. I think here it is more El Salvadoran (?) so ordering those types of items on the menu will result in a better experience. The Carne Asada fries were very good. We ordered papusas and the steak and plantains. The plantains were fried perfectly and were delicious when paired with the steak it came with. What a good combination of savory and sweet! Papusas were crisp, not soggy and I could barely sop up the beans and cheese that came with both dishes. The beer we had (don't remember what its called) was very good, light enough to match with the heavier food we were eating, but not so light that it was lacking flavor. 

Would definitely come again. Great service as well.
author: Emily H.

description:
Great food.  Caters to my vegan needs.  

This restaurant is ran mostly by a family from El Salvador.  They are all super friendly and cheery.  When "Mom" makes the green salsa (which isn't very often because it is very time consuming) I am a very happy person.

Good and cheeeeeeeeeeeeeeeep.

DO IT!
author: Arthur E.

description:
I can't believe no one has reviewed this place yet.  Well, to be fair, until a few months ago there was a Vietnamese restaurant at the same location and I only stumbled into it b/c I was looking for mediocre cheap food and figured I'd run across the street.

OMG.  Cheesy goodness.  The vegetarian combo was huge, delicious, and cheap.  I strongly recommend checking this place out.  The staff is friendly, the food is cheap, and one meal is really 2 meals.  Eat there.  Did I mention it's cheap?
author: Bianca P.

description:
Yummy menudo!

When you order, you have a choice of with or without  vegetables.  I thought this meant with or without sides.  Turns out it really is about having vegetables in one's menudo.  I think it made things taste better.  Definately order the menudo with some pupusas.  I just wish they were open on Sundays.
author: Jack R.

description: Nice combo plates and you get a good amount of food (enough for 2-3 meals) in them. Everything was tasty. It took a while to get food to go - I'd love to get a menu and be able to call ahead. Good prices, not-overly-friendly service, I'm looking forward to going back - maybe someday I'll even have a good enough workout to try the carne asada fries.
author: Lisa K.

description:
i can't believe i haven't yelped OLIVO'S yet.

well, it's probably because i don't want you to know about it.

and by "it" i mean the fact that they not only serve CARNE ASADA FRIES (good luck finding them outside of SD; i heard baldo's is closed in the east bay), but they also serve my favorite - CARNITAS FRIES!  

the staff are always nice and they usually know me (and my order!) when i come in.

now that you've read this, don't tell anybody!  this review will self-destruct in 10 seconds...
author: dan a.

description:
If you like your pupupas with a side of tranny, or if like me, you live in the neighborhood and it's raining so hard you want to go somewhere en route to Rite Aid with one step out of your way, here you go.

We had the two pupusas revueltas and then the meals were an excellent steak ranchero and the pork chops.  Everything was excellent.  

The ladies who lunch there are the Tenderloin's finest sweaty-balls-in-nylons crew, as well as their (many) admirers.  Under the blaze of lights the 5 o'clock shadow is a little darker.  I love every single thing about this place.

We'll SO be back.

P.S.  This place was Vietnamese?  I must be old, I remember it being Long's a really bad Chinese place, but that was about 15 yrs ago, and I probably just blocked it out of sight till Pupusas came along.
author: Enzo L.

description:
"link me the review you make, IT BETTA BE GOOD OR ELSE LOL and by good i mean, tell the people the truth about OLIVOS!!! the man's ass crack!! The open bathroom!! the 2 hour wait for food, the greesy soup and pupusas!! THE TRUTH CHARLIE!! LOL" -from my good, angry friend "the pupusa queen"

With these instructions in mind...

Our lunch took 30 minutes to arrive.  Some big dude at the table across from us got so angry about the wait that he yelled at the waitress/manager/proprietor (there was only one person working) and walked out before his food arrived.  This same man had his ass crack and his belly hanging out of his shirt.  The bathroom door was wide open.  The pupusas and the soup we ordered were extra greasy, and they forgot the cabbage!  Who forgets cabbage!?!?  I wouldn't go back here.
author: Charles C.

description:
Where the trannies at?

Maybe our group of 30+ scared them away or maybe since it was raining out (rain+runny mascara+wigs = unhappy trannies).

Trannies aside, this is a great place. I had the super fattening pupusas which were great. A couple of my friends had the Steak Salvadorean and at $8.50, I felt kinda dumb that I didn't get it myself. It came in a huge portions and tasted great (I Star Jones-ed some) 

*to 'Star Jones' is to eat most of the food from someone else's plate*

I'll definitely be back again to eat some steak, find some trannies, and check the time on their 'high class quartz clock'. PS the lady that works here is super super nice and the music is fun to dance along to. No wonder trannies love this place!

+744 stars! (only 4 stars in the review because I haven't tried some other things on the menu)
author: Rocky K.

description:
The shrimp tacos were pretty darn good.  Having spent time in So. Cal. I have been craving a decent San Francisco shrimp taco experience.  While they lacked the cabbage and distinct white sauce that comes on Baja-style seafood tacos down south, they were VERY flavorful.  And sans sauce, they were probably much better for me.  

Try 'em!  Two for under $6.  But be sure to bring cash because that's all they take.
author: Melissa S.

description:
I've had some amazing pupusas in my time. So I was happy to look up reviews for this spot that is literally a block away from my house! This place definitely serves it up!! The Pupusas are not greasy, and have a perfect balance of cheese and beans inside. Also, I've never been to a Pupuseria where they were made this fast. I was shocked!! I had the Pupusa plate that came with beans and rice. The rice was amazing, and it was reasonably priced! My only complaint is the cabbage that they give to serve as a condiment to the pupusas was totally bland, and I usually eat that stuff up all by itself. The salsa they give was super mild too and not what I'm used to. Oh well... 4 stars regardless!

Oh yeah, Mexican Coca Cola... mmmm sugar!
author: Amber G.

description:
Thanks Yelpers! i did not believe i would ever find some carne asada fries  or Cali Burritos in SF, but alas i found one of the two!!

Granted that I have not tried the rest of their food, these 4 stars are for the Carne Asada fries that fix my craving.  Although they are not like Lolita's Carne Asada fries back in my hometown, when you're in the mood for some So Cali style carne asada fries this is a great place.  

Oh and the tranny bit everyone writes about is really true...
author: Cindy M.

description: carne asada Fries!!!!! Best post drinking food:)
author: Julie R.

description: Real good pupusas made by a real El Salvadorian family... I assume, haha. Found this place a couple of weeks ago & have been there twice now. Really inexpensive food, that hits the spot. I usually order in take-out & it works pretty well seeing that I only live a 10 minute walk away. I would recommend for those lazy days when you dont feel like going to far & want a home-cooked type meal on your hands for not too much. I would definitely give it a try.
author: Lily R.

description: Nothing to rave about. I had the super carnitas burrito, it was ok but not extraordinary. The people working there seem completely disinterested, and almost bothered you're there. And don't expect to be served, if you need anything, stand up and go directly at the counter.
author: Delphine C.

description:
I use to enoy going to Olivo's but i've noticed that the service there totally lacks. The food it good but the owner's daughter/waitress has such an attitude. Everytime i walk in the place is empty yet it takes forever to get our menus and drinks.  We never get our check unless we get up and ask for it. 
It's too bad, since the food it good but not worth the hassle.
author: Michelle A.

description: Love this restaurant!  I go for the carnitas plate and the beef soup.  You definitely cannot go wrong with this joint.  Portions are fantastic!  Beware, it's cash only.
author: Brian Y.

description:
I want to do 2 different reviews for this place. I went during lunch time and here are the positives.

1) AWESOME Pupusa dish. I loved it. This is why I'm probably going to go back there when I finish writing this.
2) Price was right. Very right.
3) Beer

The negative was the guac. I'm not sure what happened there. I've never actually had bad guac till then. But this stuff smelled like rotten eggs. It had that very sulfery smell to it. I couldn't believe it. I thought maybe they put eggs in it or something. I guess it was just very very rotten avocado. 

Anyway, on one hand it was great. Just had some sourness to the appetizer.

Again, I'm still going back.
author: Roderic C.

description: Found this today on yelp. Tried it and loved it. Delicious and clean and the service was friendly. And bc it's in the middle of the tenderloin I got parking pretty easily.
author: Alastair M.

description:
Absolutely delicious. And inexpensive. And decent seating area that doesn't feel like you are on top of your neighbors. Wonderful selection of Salvadorian cuisine (thus, no Al Pastor!). 

I found their shrimp & fish tacos to be my favorite for a long time--well seasoned, not fried too much, and generous servings compared to the rest of the ingredients of the tacos. All chicken items are fantastic. The fried plantains are perfectly crispy and soft. The Carne Asada is always a hit. Perfect. Oh, and the serving of avocado is ridiculously huge. Another huge plus. 

One small complaint: The chips are not homemade. Maybe I'm spoiled, but it does make a difference. I definitely did see bags of chips--I can't remember the brand--sitting behind the counter that were then transferred into bowls for each table. 
AND, they aren't open on Sundays...what am I supposed to eat to soak up Saturday night?! Kidding aside, I really wish they were 24/7. 

I've read people complaining about the service. Here's the thing: The servers are plenty pleasant, just don't expect to have your ass-kissed. I find the younger woman really lovely. They aren't super fast but to be honest, I really think we've gotten totally confused about how long it ought to take to cook food. I mean, truly cook it. They do that at Olivio's and you can tell. It's all made to order and is always good.
author: Sarah H.

description: What is bullshit about most of these reviews is that there is no mention of the motherfucking REGIA!!!! yeah the papusas are dope and all but dude any place that serves 32 oz ice cold beers with papusas is the greatest place in the goddamn world. I'm so riding for this spot and I've only been once but man shit is real.  Thank god too cause I've been in need of good latin food within minimal hungover walking distance and the bag of dicks that is El Super Burrito wasn't about to nurse me. Good food and big ass bottles of beer, hell yeah I fucks with it.
author: Sergio O.

description: Good salsa and good papusas.  I tried a carne asada burrito once and kept having to spit out pieces of fat and bone.  Also a bit too salty.  Their salsa makes up for the other deficiencies.
author: Michael R.

description:
Great food - pupusas, california burrito, and shrimp tacos are must haves.  Black beans and rice here are also incredible.  All at ridiculously cheap prices.  Beers are also easy on the wallet ($2.75 for domestic).

Downsides are the neighborhood - more than once someone has come into the bar area to beg for money while I was waiting for take-out, decor - looks a little run down, and service - everyone is nice, but they just don't seem to know themselves if it is a sit-down restaurant or take-out joint and service levels fluctuate between the two.
author: Brendan M.

description:
This was the first time I've ever ordered Pupusas.   They are kind of like Gordita flatbread stuffed with Pork and Cheese.  My god are these things delicious.  

My suggestion to you?  STOP being a pu pussy and order some Pupusas from Olivo's NOW!  you won't regret it. 

Oh and I love the ladies that work there.
author: Buddy Garrity L.

description: One of my go to places for Mexican / Salvadorian food in the Tenderloin. The plates are inexpensive and usually plentiful. I love the pupusas
author: Mike T.

description: I have been missing out on this for 20 years? Relying on Victor's, Shalimar and all the frankly medoicre Thai places around for so long I shame myself for not coming here sooner. I've probably walked by honestly about a 1000 times and thought maybe 3 times that it must be good. I love and miss the trannie hookers Larkin had in spades 10 years ago but I always kind of felt like I didn't want really want to eat in Taxi Driver territory. I didn't know there were delicious fresh fried plantains. Or amazingly perfect salsa in my estimation; meaning light, not too spicy, on the thinner side, using good quality tomatoes with just the right amount of onions and cilantro. Then I got to the pupusas which come with an extra helping of clearly homemade love and pickled something. Amazing. As for service, they were perfectly nice. Sure they're a little dismissive but with food that good in a formerly hardcore gnarls and still pretty gross stretch of Larkin I think it's appropriate.  I'm just dreading the end of their lease like so many other SF casualties. Go now and enjoy the Boyle Heights ambience or take it para llevar if you're snooty like that.
author: Smelly S.

description: solid papusas!  family owned and they once served me the best black refried beans I have ever tasted!
author: Steve W.

description:
I'll give it four stars though my boyfriend would probably be less kind since he always seems to get bad service and spotty food. I on the other hand have never had an issue with the food or the service. 

The portions are beyond generous for the prices and the chili rellenos are comfort food crack but without the long term impact to your health (not that they won't have a health impact just that compared to crack you should be okay).

I think the burritos are not up to the quality of the other items I have had so if you go try some of the other things on the menu that are unfortnaunately not that widely available on this side of Market.
author: Tara A.

description:
I finally popped in for lunch on Saturday and am pretty damn pleased I did, the food was great and the restaurant has a great family-run feel to it.

At the recommendation of my new friend Will, owner of nearby Leland Teas (http://www.yelp.com/biz/6CaVZoVaGx5J7x4_h-_UfA), I tried the bean, cheese and pork Papusas.  Let's just say that I was glad Will was around to guide me as I thoroughly enjoyed them -- order with rice and beans for a fully satisfying meal.

They have all sorts of main platters (grilled chicken, steak, some seafood) and more standard mexican fare...but i'd suggest trying the papusas, good stuff!
author: John R.

description: Carne Asada Fries, say it with me folks, Carne Asada Fries, Carne... well you get the picture. These are the absolute best, most fattening, most fantastic fries ever, and I am a french fry fanatic! I also, love Carne Asada, these babies are perfectly marinated, with mouthwatering steak, cheese, guacamole, atop perfectly cooked french fries. A friend of mine introduced me to this place, and now I am a fan. I will admit that I have yet to try anything else on the menu, but I will get around to it. I just can't get past the Carne Asada Fries!
author: Anthony K.

description: I read the reviews before coming here. Right away I realized who the grumpy waitress was. However, I asked her if they could make me a combo that wasn't on the menu and she said she would ask ( without any sign that I was annoying her ). They did what I wanted and the food was fantastic. The reviewers are correct about the lack of friendliness but I don't know if I would have noticed as much if I hadn't been made aware of this by the reviews. I will go back again . I would have given 5 stars if she was friendlier. I'm still stuffed so I'm going to take a nap.
author: Patrick M.

description: This place is awesome!  I haven't found many, or any, places that have california burritos in SF, but I was lucky to find Olivo's.  After searching a bunch of taquerias in the Mission, I pretty much gave up hope.  Who knew that all I had to do was walk a few blocks away for a delicious california burrito and carne asada fries.  I don't recommend ordering both unless you're going to split it with another person or two. But, I haven't had carne asada fries or a california burrito in a long time, so I ordered both in the hopes that I could finish some for lunch and the rest for dinner.  Big mistake.  I finished about 1/3 of each for lunch and was still full for dinner, even after going to the gym. The fries aren't what I was used to from the ones they have in San Diego, so be prepared for that.  They're cut a little wider and seemed to be cooked a different way, it's not bad, but it's different.
author: Joe N.

description: I was visiting from out of town staying south of Union Square, and desperate for something to eat that wasn't in a hotel.  While the walk to this point was kind of sketchy, the food was well worth it. The carnitas tacos were pitch-perfect and the folks there were all very friendly.
author: Lane M.

description: The service was not friendly.  They weren't rude, but I did feel like I was inconveniencing them.  The burrito I ordered was certainly sub-par.  It was mostly rice- cheap filler.  There was microscopic amounts of the sour cream, guac, lettuce, and cheese that was promised.  The carnitas was plentiful, but not super flavorful.  It was subpar, but not horrible, hence the two stars.  Still, I won't be back.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: I have never been disappointed here.  Although I was boycotting Olivo's for a couple months because the older lady that runs the place was kinda unsmiley one day, but that's whatevs.  Everything we've had here has been great, the plantains, pupusas, carne asada fries, and all the breakfast menu items are good bets.  It's just a good neighborhood spot to grab some spanish food without having to go to the mission.
author: courtney l.

description: For those of you from Southern California searching for something like home, this is the place. Start with the California Burrito. Everything I have tried is great. After 10 years of trying Mexican food all through out the Mission I would say this is my favorite.
author: Fancy P.

description:
ok substitute if you can't make it to the mission.

papusas were alright. no awsome slaw to go with it. salsa was ok. yuca frita, i love, but got some pork with it, which was not what i ordered. boo. the waitress said they had a side, but whateves. boyfriend liked the pork, fine. but still, not what i ordered. in a pinch i'll go, but not what i crave.
author: Meredith K.

description:
kär-nay-esä-da fries...

not like the way San Diegans make 'em...
and you might wanna call in ahead of time to pick 'em up...
BUT...YES!  they have it here!  =D
author: Nancy T.

description:
I think I was on my way to the post office with my girlfriend and we stopped in for a bite.  I'm a big taco fan, so I ordered the crunchy kind while my girlfriend ordered the soft kind.  The food came out super quick and what I had was nice crunchy satisfaction.  My girlfriend's was good too, but the second time I went in and ordered the soft tacos and the beef was super dry and the salsa tasted like Pace.

In a city that charges two fifty for tacos that I get in the San Joaquin valley for a dollar, this place was a refreshing change.  I think their taco's are a buck fifty or a buck twenty five.

Way better than El Tesero, but I think I'll keep Chunky's as my taco stop.
author: Ashby U.

description: Fantastic veggie pupusas.  Some of the best I have ever had.  I tried the breakfast burrito too and kept on day dreaming of it a week later.  Good stuff people.
author: Ned N.

description: Not bad at all. Used to live around the corner from this place, but finally went a year after moving out. Had the Carne Asada burrito. pretty massive. The joint was a little divey (the ceiling was leaking right onto the table behind ours), but it wasn't crowded at all and I was in serious need of a burrito so I got it quick. may have to go back some time to try the Pork Chops and Carne Asada fries.
author: Stu C.

description: Don't expect San Diego carne asada fries here. The papusas were good though.
author: sunny c.

description: Thank you for the ever so comforting food when I need it most. And always having Negra Modelo. Especially when I need it most.
author: Lauren S.

description: Ate here last night. Pretty bomb. I go for the California Burritos and Carne Asada Fries alone.
author: Mike B.

description:
Good friends took us here last night for the first time! Scrumptious Salvadorian food hand-made by a really sweet family. Pupusas rock, (fried perfect- not too doughy, just right) as does the salsa, (that we had refilled many times over), the fried yucca, and the fish tacos. They're not on the menu yet- but we asked for them and they delivered. They were fantastic- very lightly floured fresh chunks of very flavorful fish. Make sure to get a delish cold Mexican beer to compliment! 
Authentic, rich and tasty- not missing the Mission at all with this one!
author: lisa t.

description: Third time I have been here and I am still satisfied with delivery of food and attention to flavor. The pupusas, beans, sour cream with fried plantains dish ...super yummmmm! This place surpasses any other pupusa places I have been to. I have to admit the place is kind of a dive but the prices are affordable and the food delicious!
author: mary s.

description: Carne Asada Fries are HERE! Everything else at this place is good (i.e. pupusas), but this is the holy grail of mexican food in the city... they have Carne Asada Fries! And it's damn good too.
author: Tuan N.

description:
Thank you fellow SF Yelpers. This place was awesome. Oh, and so is the warning about the trannies. Though there was no crotch grabbing or anything that exciting.
My girlfriend and I are big fans of Salvadorian food, there are a few restaurants in Phoenix we go to. And Olivo's held up to the best of them.
We got the pupusas, pinto beans and rice. They were amazing, we had both the cheese and the bean and cheese. I had a couple of the Salvadorian beer Suprema, which was really good, too, light and almost sweet, like the other Salvadorian beers I have had. The chips and salsa were not bad, either, the salsa was hot and tasted fresh.
As we waited for our dinner, we could see the woman in the back making the pupusas by hand. It doesn't get any better than that. The family runs the restaurant, mother, father and daughter, which was obvious as soon as we walked in.
